--- Derek James <blue5432@...> wrote:
<snip>
> I agree with Ken that the representation of the
> cards
> is a major issue, but I'm afraid I don't quite
> understand your explanation of how you're handling
> it.
>  In this case:
> 
> King/clubs     2/hearts     10/spades
> 10/spades      King/clubs   2/hearts

We don't have to represent suits because they have no
role in concentration.  I'm planning to start with a
very small deck and work up if I'm successful.  So the
entire deck might be 1 1 2 2 3 3!

> How many inputs does your NN have?  It sounds like
> 12
> from your explanation...is that right?  So for the
> first row/first column, you're going to have one
> boolean input, either 0 or 1 depending on whether
> there's a card there?  But what is the other input
> going to be? 

Let's say we use the six card deck describe above. 
For each of the six positions we have 5 binary inputs.
One input is for whether there is a card there or not.
Another if or whether the card is face down or now.
If there is a card and its face up, then the other
three inputs are for its identity, 1, 2 or 3.

I could reduce the number of inputs to three by using
binary coding: 000 no card, 111 face down, 001 ace,
010 deuce, 100 trey.  I would like to hear opinions
about whether that's a good idea.  If this works it
makes it easier to enlarge the deck.

> If your inputs range from 0 to 1, are you
> representing
> each type of card as a value range (e.g. King/clubs
> is
> from 0 to 0.33, 2/hearts is from .33 to .66, etc.)?

Ken thought it was not a good idea to use this
representation, and I'm inclined to agree.

> I also think that Concentration sounds like an
> interesting test domain, and I'm interested in how
> card games are represented.  

There is big money in Poker playing programs, but that
is quite a difficult challenge.  I have no plans to
attempt it.

m
<snip>
